title: How to Act Like a Caveman

steps.headline: Gather your materials.
steps.description: You'll need a soft tape measure and enough faux-fur fabric for whatever size you'd like your costume to be. For a full-length costume, measure the length from your shoulder to your knee and your body's circumference, or the measurement around your chest under your arms. You'll also need fabric shears or scissors and, if you've got a knack for sewing, a sewing kit or machine. Fortunately, making a primitive caveman costume doesn't require any sewing! It is, however, one option if you like to sew. Be careful handling shears, scissors, and other sharp objects and, if you need to, get a parent to help or supervise. If you just want to go for a loincloth look, get enough fabric to wrap around your waistline (and bustline if you're a cavewoman) a several times, with the amount of coverage you're comfortable with.

steps.headline: Cut fabric for your full-length or loincloth costume.
steps.description:
Once you've decided on the size of your costume, cut and tear the fabric. Since you're going for a prehistoric look, you can just make a first cut with the shears, then tear the rest of the way following as straight a line as you can – no need to be too neat! A loincloth is easy: just cut a length of fabric three or four times the size of your waist (and, if necessary, bustline). For a full length costume, cut two rectangles. They should be as long as your shoulder-to-knee measurement and as wide as half your circumference measurement. Cut a triangle shape off of the top of each rectangle for the arm hole. If you don't know how to sew, you'll need to make your rectangles about 3 or 4 inches longer and wider, so you'll have more room to attach them by tying them together
Make sure the triangles line up so when you attach them they're both on the same side and the outside fabric of both rectangles faces out.

steps.headline: Sew your full-length costume together.
steps.description: If you're sewing, first stitch the seam that starts where the bottoms of the triangle arm hole line up. Stitch the opposite length next, and leave enough room from the top for your arm to fit through plus two or three inches. Finally, stitch the shoulder seam, or the top side from the triangle hole to the edge.

steps.headline: Tie your full-length costume together.
steps.description: Instead of sewing, you can cut strips a couple inches long and about an inch wide all the way down the sides and top of your rectangles. Imperfections are okay, so don't worry about making all the strips uniform. Make sure you don't cut the bottom edge, the triangle arm hole, or the shoulder hole on the opposite side of the triangle into strips, these will of course be the holes for your arms and legs. Tie your strips together on each side with simple, tight knots.

steps.headline: Wrap your loincloth around your waist and legs.
steps.description: If you don't have time to make a full-size costume, the loincloth can be a quick fix. Hold the fabric with one hand against a hip, weave it between it your legs in one direction, bring it around your backside and through your legs again in the opposite direction. Pull it so it's tight but still comfortable, and then wrap it around your waist once. Hold it in place with fabric pins, safety pins, bobby pins, a secure clip, or give yourself enough slack with your fabric to tie it very tight. Remember, prehistoric people didn't have any footwear and mostly went barefoot everywhere, so don't bring any shoes or socks with your costume.

steps.headline: Make a simple top if you're a cavewoman.
steps.description: You can use a similar technique to make the top for a more feminine costume. Take measurements of your chest and cut enough fabric to give you the coverage you'd like. Wrap the fabric around your torso and securely fasten it with pins, a clip, or leave yourself enough material to tie it.

steps.headline: Accessorize your costume.
steps.description: Now that you've made the basic costume, you can embellish it with accessories and props to complete your look. Try using a glue- or staple-gun to attach fur along sleeves or edges (make sure you're not wearing the costume while you do so). Distress the costume by adding cuts and fringe along edges.

steps.headline: Make a papier mâché club.
steps.description: You can easily make a prop to complete your prehistoric look. Mix 2 parts white glue and 1 part water, and cut or tear newspaper into strips. Dip the newspaper strips into the glue mixture and wrap them around an empty paper towel or wrapping paper roll. Let it dry for a day or so when you're done, then find some brown paint and give it a couple coats when it's finished drying. Try to make one end thicker than the other to form a club shape. You can also use a mix of 1 part flour and 1 part water instead of the glue mixture.

steps.headline: Use leftover fabric to make head, ankle, and wrist bands.
steps.description: Don't put any of your fabric to waste! If you made a full-length costume, cut the triangles from the shoulder hole into strips. Tie them around your forehead, wrists, arms, or ankles to accessorize your costume.

steps.headline: Give yourself a primitive makeover.
steps.description: Finish your look off with makeup: make your face look dirty, like you just came back from a mammoth hunt. Use non-toxic coloring to black out a few teeth. Get a hair product with good, matte or non-shiny hold and give yourself a really messy caveman mane.

steps.headline: Find a good caveman name.
steps.description: Whether you've made your own costume or bought one from the store, you need a new name to get into the prehistoric spirit! Go with something short, preferably one syllable, and that sounds kind of like a grunt.

steps.headline: Talk like a caveman.
steps.description: You've got the look down, but you've got to talk the talk. Stay in character: don't use words like I, you, or us, and try to avoid proper grammar. Talk in grunts and hand motions rather than complete sentences.

steps.headline: Don't use electronics.
steps.description: Put your phone out of sight for this costume party. One moment you're looking at your phone, and before you know it you'll be flying planes and inventing the internet. Leave the picture taking and tagging for the more evolved party-goers: remember, you're still making cave drawings and selfies won't be around for ten thousand years!

methods.name: Acting like a Caveman Every Day

steps.headline: Go Paleo.
steps.description:
Dressing up and acting like a caveman can be fun for cosplay or Halloween, but there can be perks in your daily life and wellness, too. Going on a high-protein, high-fiber Paleo diet can help you lose weight and might make you less likely to develop diseases like diabetes, cancer, and heart issues. Eat lots of fresh lean meat and fish, fruits, vegetables, healthy fats, and raw foods
Avoid processed foods (so no packaged or canned food), wheat and other grains, legumes (like peanuts and beans), dairy, refined sugar, and refined vegetable oils (like canola oil).

steps.headline: Move and travel like a caveman.
steps.description: In addition to sending your diet back to the Stone Age, make an effort to walk and run more instead of traveling by car. Spend several hours each day outside. Just make sure you're protected from the elements and not risking your health and safety.

steps.headline: Put down the electronics and other modern conveniences.
steps.description: Getting away from modern technology and conveniences can help you improve your focus and become more present, even if just for a day or two per week. Putting down the electronics, paying more attention to what you're eating, and getting more exercise, your brain and body can become more balanced and energized. Set certain days or times aside to live "off the grid" that you won't have to constantly check your smartphone or computer. Do away with fast food and take time to cook your own meals.

text:
Making a Great Caveman Costume Gather your materials. You'll need a soft tape measure and enough faux-fur fabric for whatever size you'd like your costume to be. For a full-length costume, measure the length from your shoulder to your knee and your body's circumference, or the measurement around your chest under your arms. You'll also need fabric shears or scissors and, if you've got a knack for sewing, a sewing kit or machine. Fortunately, making a primitive caveman costume doesn't require any sewing! It is, however, one option if you like to sew. Be careful handling shears, scissors, and other sharp objects and, if you need to, get a parent to help or supervise. If you just want to go for a loincloth look, get enough fabric to wrap around your waistline (and bustline if you're a cavewoman) a several times, with the amount of coverage you're comfortable with. Cut fabric for your full-length or loincloth costume. Once you've decided on the size of your costume, cut and tear the fabric. Since you're going for a prehistoric look, you can just make a first cut with the shears, then tear the rest of the way following as straight a line as you can – no need to be too neat! A loincloth is easy: just cut a length of fabric three or four times the size of your waist (and, if necessary, bustline). For a full length costume, cut two rectangles. They should be as long as your shoulder-to-knee measurement and as wide as half your circumference measurement. Cut a triangle shape off of the top of each rectangle for the arm hole. If you don't know how to sew, you'll need to make your rectangles about 3 or 4 inches longer and wider, so you'll have more room to attach them by tying them together
Make sure the triangles line up so when you attach them they're both on the same side and the outside fabric of both rectangles faces out. Sew your full-length costume together. If you're sewing, first stitch the seam that starts where the bottoms of the triangle arm hole line up. Stitch the opposite length next, and leave enough room from the top for your arm to fit through plus two or three inches. Finally, stitch the shoulder seam, or the top side from the triangle hole to the edge. Tie your full-length costume together. Instead of sewing, you can cut strips a couple inches long and about an inch wide all the way down the sides and top of your rectangles. Imperfections are okay, so don't worry about making all the strips uniform. Make sure you don't cut the bottom edge, the triangle arm hole, or the shoulder hole on the opposite side of the triangle into strips, these will of course be the holes for your arms and legs. Tie your strips together on each side with simple, tight knots. Wrap your loincloth around your waist and legs. If you don't have time to make a full-size costume, the loincloth can be a quick fix. Hold the fabric with one hand against a hip, weave it between it your legs in one direction, bring it around your backside and through your legs again in the opposite direction. Pull it so it's tight but still comfortable, and then wrap it around your waist once. Hold it in place with fabric pins, safety pins, bobby pins, a secure clip, or give yourself enough slack with your fabric to tie it very tight. Remember, prehistoric people didn't have any footwear and mostly went barefoot everywhere, so don't bring any shoes or socks with your costume. Make a simple top if you're a cavewoman. You can use a similar technique to make the top for a more feminine costume. Take measurements of your chest and cut enough fabric to give you the coverage you'd like. Wrap the fabric around your torso and securely fasten it with pins, a clip, or leave yourself enough material to tie it. Completing Your Look Accessorize your costume. Now that you've made the basic costume, you can embellish it with accessories and props to complete your look. Try using a glue- or staple-gun to attach fur along sleeves or edges (make sure you're not wearing the costume while you do so). Distress the costume by adding cuts and fringe along edges. Make a papier mâché club. You can easily make a prop to complete your prehistoric look. Mix 2 parts white glue and 1 part water, and cut or tear newspaper into strips. Dip the newspaper strips into the glue mixture and wrap them around an empty paper towel or wrapping paper roll. Let it dry for a day or so when you're done, then find some brown paint and give it a couple coats when it's finished drying. Try to make one end thicker than the other to form a club shape. You can also use a mix of 1 part flour and 1 part water instead of the glue mixture. Use leftover fabric to make head, ankle, and wrist bands. Don't put any of your fabric to waste! If you made a full-length costume, cut the triangles from the shoulder hole into strips. Tie them around your forehead, wrists, arms, or ankles to accessorize your costume. Give yourself a primitive makeover. Finish your look off with makeup: make your face look dirty, like you just came back from a mammoth hunt. Use non-toxic coloring to black out a few teeth. Get a hair product with good, matte or non-shiny hold and give yourself a really messy caveman mane. Playing the Part Find a good caveman name. Whether you've made your own costume or bought one from the store, you need a new name to get into the prehistoric spirit! Go with something short, preferably one syllable, and that sounds kind of like a grunt. Talk like a caveman. You've got the look down, but you've got to talk the talk. Stay in character: don't use words like I, you, or us, and try to avoid proper grammar. Talk in grunts and hand motions rather than complete sentences. Don't use electronics. Put your phone out of sight for this costume party. One moment you're looking at your phone, and before you know it you'll be flying planes and inventing the internet. Leave the picture taking and tagging for the more evolved party-goers: remember, you're still making cave drawings and selfies won't be around for ten thousand years! Acting like a Caveman Every Day Go Paleo. Dressing up and acting like a caveman can be fun for cosplay or Halloween, but there can be perks in your daily life and wellness, too. Going on a high-protein, high-fiber Paleo diet can help you lose weight and might make you less likely to develop diseases like diabetes, cancer, and heart issues. Eat lots of fresh lean meat and fish, fruits, vegetables, healthy fats, and raw foods
Avoid processed foods (so no packaged or canned food), wheat and other grains, legumes (like peanuts and beans), dairy, refined sugar, and refined vegetable oils (like canola oil). Move and travel like a caveman. In addition to sending your diet back to the Stone Age, make an effort to walk and run more instead of traveling by car. Spend several hours each day outside. Just make sure you're protected from the elements and not risking your health and safety. Put down the electronics and other modern conveniences. Getting away from modern technology and conveniences can help you improve your focus and become more present, even if just for a day or two per week. Putting down the electronics, paying more attention to what you're eating, and getting more exercise, your brain and body can become more balanced and energized. Set certain days or times aside to live "off the grid" that you won't have to constantly check your smartphone or computer. Do away with fast food and take time to cook your own meals.

You'll need a soft tape measure and enough faux-fur fabric for whatever size you'd like your costume to be.
For a full-length costume, measure the length from your shoulder to your knee and your body's circumference, or the measurement around your chest under your arms.
You'll also need fabric shears or scissors and, if you've got a knack for sewing, a sewing kit or machine.
Fortunately, making a primitive caveman costume doesn't require any sewing!
It is, however, one option if you like to sew.
Be careful handling shears, scissors, and other sharp objects and, if you need to, get a parent to help or supervise.
If you just want to go for a loincloth look, get enough fabric to wrap around your waistline (and bustline if you're a cavewoman) a several times, with the amount of coverage you're comfortable with.

A loincloth is easy: just cut a length of fabric three or four times the size of your waist (and, if necessary, bustline).
For a full length costume, cut two rectangles.
They should be as long as your shoulder-to-knee measurement and as wide as half your circumference measurement.
Cut a triangle shape off of the top of each rectangle for the arm hole.

If you don't know how to sew, you'll need to make your rectangles about 3 or 4 inches longer and wider, so you'll have more room to attach them by tying them together

Tie your strips together on each side with simple, tight knots.

If you don't have time to make a full-size costume, the loincloth can be a quick fix.

Remember, prehistoric people didn't have any footwear and mostly went barefoot everywhere, so don't bring any shoes or socks with your costume.
Make a simple top if you're a cavewoman.
You can use a similar technique to make the top for a more feminine costume.
Take measurements of your chest and cut enough fabric to give you the coverage you'd like.

Completing Your Look Accessorize your costume.
Now that you've made the basic costume, you can embellish it with accessories and props to complete your look.

Distress the costume by adding cuts and fringe along edges.
Make a papier mâché club.
You can easily make a prop to complete your prehistoric look.

You can also use a mix of 1 part flour and 1 part water instead of the glue mixture.
